half the problem with "renewable" energy sources, is that they aren't really renewable, and only one of the four "big" renewable sources that isn't a direct threat to the environment it aims to protect is geothermal power- Wind turbines are a threat to both migratory and native birds that take up massive amounts of land, Solar farms are the same, but worse- and large scale hydro power comes at the cost of a similarly massive environmental impact as a vast amount of area needs to be flooded, and redirecting rivers for this purpose destroys the areas native fish live in.

All of this is not even accounting for the costs of actually building and maintaining these things, as an example- Solar and Geothermal plants take vast amounts of ground water at such great rates that they are contributing to California's drought more than the millionaires who were watering their lawns in the middle of it, A wind turbine takes 80 gallons of oil JUST as lubricant each year- I'm not talking vegetable oil, I'm talking refined crude oil- the average wind farm is about 150 turbines, that's 12,000 gallons of oil used YEARLY on one turbine farm that after 20 years will have to be taken down because the blades of wind turbines are made of a toxic resin with a surprisingly short shelf life before it starts flaking apart and poisoning the environment! Hydro has the lowest direct costs for non renewables outside vast amounts of cement and rebar... but again, putting one up is a massive ecological problem that can and will cause devastation to the native wildlife instead.

TLDR in a LOT of ways, "renewable" energy sources are worse for the environment than Fossil fuel plants, and SIGNIFICANTLY worse for the environment than Nuclear power, furthermore the belief that they are purely better- is a scam.

This interesting article does not answer the first and simplest of questions on this matter, namely, why is one generating method chosen over the others?  In a word, cost.  Least expensive of all is gas, indicatively about 1-1.5 mln usd/MW.  Adding a combined cycle, 1.5-2.  Coal goes for 2-2.5.  Hydroelectric 2-4. Solar 1-1.25 (has gone down a lot over the years). Wind 1.3-1.5 onshore, a bit more offshore.  Nuclear 6-8! Ouch!  The first pair is relatively inexpensive, but you must buy the fuel, gas, coal, diesel, fuel oil for its entire lifespan.  Nuclear too, but this cost is minimal.  Then comes the time required to build each installation.  Wind and solar are quickest, a thermal plant for gas, coal or liquid fuels can take a couple of years, hydro can be 2-5 years or more, depending on size and complexity, and nuclear...10-15 years! But this is not all of the story.  Then comes the percentage of hours in a year that each generation method may be used.  Solar works only with sunshine, much less on cloudy days and not at all during the night. Better in summer than in winter, and closest to the equator helps.  On average, 20-35% of the time.  Same with wind. Just works when the wind blows. Similar percentage.  Next comes hydro.  Most dams create a lake, the higher the better, the more electricity it will generate.  But then usually there are rainy and dry seasons, so they can operate a third of the time, except those dams on the biggest rivers, where it can be 50% or more.  Fossil fuel plants of course can operate round the clock, but they are expensive on a dollar per MWh basis, so they are used when there is no better option, typically during the evening electricity demand peak (when prices are highest, obviously).  Here nuclear reigns supreme: it can generate upwards of 95% of the hours of the year, effortlessly.  So far supply.  Demand (and selling prices) change throughout the hours of the day and with the seasons, or special events.  Lowest at night when people sleep, then it goes up in the morning, and is highest in the evening when lights are on, food is cooked, tv is watched, etc.  Also on unseasonably cold or hot days, and during the most popular sports events.  People gather and watch the game on tv and don't consume much electricity.  Solar generation is highest between noon and early afternoon, when prices are lowest.  Wind blows when it blows.  Nuclear and hydro can take full advantage of the highest prices, and fossil fuel plants are normally lit up for peak demand.  So from this very brief introduction we see that nuclear has very high initial investment costs, it requires a long time to build, but long term it offers the lowest costs per MWh, which is the number that counts.  This leaves out the poorer countries that cannot afford the expense.  Then there is the other sticky issue, that in many countries electric generation is by public utilities, frequently state owned. Nuclear disaster and operational casualty numbers are also comparable to coal power plant worker casualties per KW, and once you factor in the deaths caused by coal pollution in the world, it’s a no brainer. Now that comparison between big disaster casualties and coal worker/pollution casualties is a bit of a bad one, but it still gives good perspective to how horrible coal is. What needs to happen to make nuclear truly safe from disasters is to increase funding to develop safer next generation reactors and there needs to be extreme regulation on operation protocol and reactor design.

You should do a video on electric vehicles as as source of battery power for the grid. The idea is that when you go home and plug in your car it does the reverse and takes electricity from the battery to put onto the grid.

In electricity usage there is on-peak times and off-peak times. On-Peak times are things like lighting load at the start of the day, when people go to work and turn on the lights, start the machines up etc. And then later when they go home and turn on there personal electronics. (Sometimes called the Duck curve due to the shape of the load on the grid.)

If you charge your car in off-peak hours (think middle of the night), the electricity is cheaper as there is less demand. Then if you supply power back to the grid during on-peak times, the price is higher and you make a net total savings, which would help offset your own electricity usage and encourage adoption.

The upside of this is a decentralized battery storage solution, without a massive infrastructure spend. This also works for things like Tesla's Powerwall.

Remember Texas? Which is run on both nuclear and fossil fuel, with only a barely-double-digit energy contribution from renewables? The compromise that I have is this: Lift the ban on breeder reactors and instead ban the extraction of new nuclear fuel from mines. Use the existing nuclear waste to produce energy through the end of the lives of the current reactors and only build new reactors if doing so would further decrease the nuclear stockpile and waste we already have. Phase nuclear out with as little waste as possible left over for future generations to deal with.

While this phase out is going on, transition towards the use of things like kinetic batteries to store energy (i.e. pinwheel or well style) and with the ability to store such energy begin widespread use of things like the typhoon generator to capture and store the energy of major storm events such that we don't need to produce any other energy. Or we could build geothermal power stations around locations like yellow stone (and simultaneously reduce the risk of a mega volcanic eruption powerful enough to end the human race). Or any number of other proposals.

Trading one evil for another just isn't the answer.

Solid video, and as part of my schooling I actually did a research project on multiple energy generation methods (mainly focusing on stationary power plants), comparing them on a very wide variety of aspects. The research was based on creating 1000kW of reliable power for a period of one year. You touched lightly on a couple of the aspects regarding renewables, and I won't go through every extensive detail of my old project, but I do want to provide a brief summary that should hopefully prove the newest-generation Nuclear plants are a SHIT TON better than what is currently available.

First, the comparison criteria. When I give actual ratings for the various energy sources, these will be relative comparisons to how well they do compared to a typical 1000kW Coal fired power plant (oil is fairly comparable, natural gas is actually quite poor as it has a lower energy density so a natural gas power plant has to consume a much larger raw volume of fuel for the same power).

ENERGY DENSITY: This means how much raw land area does a power plant of a particular type need to create the 1000kW reliably

LOCATION DEPENDENCY: This means how dependent is a particular power plant type on being placed in a specific topography (for example, you're not going to be able to put a hydro power plant in the middle of a flat desert, but several other types can work there

FUEL CONSUMPTION: This is for the raw mass of fuel needing to be consumed to provide the power

RELIABILITY: This represents how effectively a plant can provide its power output at all times, 24 hours a day. Stuff does not turn off when you're sleeping; heat for your home in cold weather, refrigeration for food, power for life-saving medical equipment in hospitals...energy needs never, ever stop

SOLID POLLUTANTS: This is the raw mass of solid waste that gets released in one form or another DURING PRODUCTION, such as airborne particulates or solid chunks of spent "stuff" that needs to be carted off somewhere

GREENHOUSE GASSES: These are the various pollutants like CO2 that get released into the atmosphere in gaseous form DURING PRODUCTION

OTHER POLLUTANTS: An often not discussed type of pollution related to the creation, maintenance and end-of-life decommissioning of various power types.

Now, with the above out of the way (this isn't all of them but it should give a good comparison), compared to a standard 1000kW Coal power plant:

SOLAR
Energy Density: Low. It can take 75 times the land area to create the same reliable power output
Location Dependency: High. Many places around the world are simply not sunny enough to produce good power output
Fuel Consumption: Zero, as may be obvious
Reliability: Low. Aside from the obvious that solar is COMPLETELY USELESS at night, even a simple weather change to cloudy weather can have a massive impact on power output, and we cannot control that
Solid Pollutants: Zero
Greenhouse Gasses: Zero
Other Pollutants: Notable. The chemicals used in fabricating panels can be quite nasty, so end-of-life replacement can be a problem. If excess Capacity was built up to store extra energy for night-time use, the chemicals and rare metals needed to build that many batteries is rather extreme

WIND
Energy Density: Atrocious. It can take up to 300 times the land area to create the same power output
Location Dependency: High. Many places around the world are not windy enough
Fuel Consumption: Zero
Reliability: Low. We have no control over how much wind there will be at any one time, so there will be notable fluctuations in production all the time.
Solid Pollutants: Zero
Greenhouse Gasses: Zero
Other Pollutants: Notable. Not only do wind turbines have similar chemical waste issues for fabrication and end-of-life replacement, the emissions from maintenance crews having to drive over such wide areas to maintain all the turbines can build up.

GEOTHERMAL
Energy Density: Good match
Location Dependency: Atrocious. The number of places in the world where you can safely drill down far enough to get good heat into water pipes without extreme risks of earthquakes breaking the pipes is very, very limited. Basic heat for your house is one thing, but electrical power production is vastly more difficult with this method
Fuel Consumption: Zero
Reliability: Low. While heat production from certain underground sources such as lava flows close to volcanos can give out plenty of heat, even a single major crack anywhere in the entire water line can shut down the entire plant and be profoundly difficult (often impossible) to repair properly
Solid Pollutants: Zero
Greenhouse Gasses: Zero
Other Pollutants: Zero, if nothing breaks

HYDRO
Energy Density: Larger one-time shift when installed given how the waterways will be adjusted both upstream and downstream
Location Dependency: High. Many places in the world don't have good waterways for a hydro dam
Fuel Consumption: Zero
Reliability: High
Solid Pollutants: One-time burst at install
Greenhouse Gasses: One-time burst at install from potential rotting vegetation
Other Pollutants: Zero

NUCLEAR FUSION
Energy Density: Not yet achieved. Fusion does not chain-react like fission, you have to constantly supply energy into the reaction to keep it going, so getting a reaction that has a net surplus of energy that you can use on top of what you need to immediately redirect back into the reactor has not yet been attained.
Location Dependency: Solid match
Fuel Consumption: Tiny (comparably)
Reliability: Uncertain since net positive reaction not achieved yet, but potentially very good
Solid Pollutants: Miniscule, and not radioactive
Greenhouse Gasses: Zero
Other Pollutants: Unknown

NUCLEAR FISSION (Going by the newer technologies like Molten Salt Reactors):
Energy Density: Perfect match
Location Dependency: Near zero. They can be placed almost anywhere and fuel is easily transportable to them
Fuel Consumption: Microscopic. In terms of raw mass in kg, Coal plants consume 500,000 times the mass of fuel
Reliability: Perfect.
Solid Pollutants: Microscopic in mass, literally a million-fold less than coal. Newer reactors like Molten Salt Reactors can also burn the fuel far more effectively, so the radioactive half life of the spent fuel is dropped from thousands of years to hundreds (which we can definitely deal with)
Greenhouse Gasses: Zero
Other Pollutants: None

The reason to go nuclear is simple. Every time energy has gotten cheaper, humanity has polluted less. Going over to coal saved the forests. Switching from whale oil to mineral oil saved the whales. Combined cycle nuclear generating plants that use closed cycle, gas core reactors can use magnetohydrodynamic cycles at the high temperature end, gas turbines in the middle, and steam turbines at the low temperature end. By varying where the energy is extracted, the end-to-end thermal efficiency can be controlled, so the electricity produced can vary faster than the thermal output of the fission reaction can be changed. A nuclear generating station that can actually follow loads would reduce demand for peaking power, dropping the need for storage, as well as reducing costs. In an environment where the difference between the cost of base load power and peaking power shrinks to the difference between running at best efficiency and at part load, power that needs a high peaking rate price will become unviable.

The Achilles' heel of renewable power is that you cannot have a dispatcher call a wind or solar electric power producer and get a guaranteed amount of energy at a guaranteed time-- the energy is either available, or it isn't and projections are only as reliable weather predictions, so the amount of power available at a given point in time is only known when that given point in time actually occurs. When a dispatcher calls a fossil fuel powered generating station, the station manager can commit to a guaranteed amount of energy at a guaranteed time. The manager checks his schedule and the power is either available, or already committed.

Large thermal generator have the extra advantage that temporary shortfalls in power can be made up for with energy available in the rotational inertia of the rotating machinery. Depending on how much was spent to connect a solar or wind generating facility to the grid, the renewable plant may not be able to push power on to the grid, if there is an energy shortfall. The 2016 (?) blackout in South Australia was caused by network conditions that prevented several windfarms operating a rated capacity from pushing power onto the grid.

I think the main reason people fear nuclear power the most (outside of it sharing a name and technology with "the bomb") is the Chernobyl disaster. Chernobyl depicts a horrifying picture of the consequences of the single worst-case-scenario a nuclear power plant can experience, and the fact those lands are still sterile of growth even uninhabitable in some parts (and will be for many years) even to this day leaves a terrifying impression to the average person of the dangers Nuclear energy can pose.

However, what most people don't realize is that the Chernobyl power plant was an absolute disaster waiting to happen, not because of the technology itself, but because of how that technology in that plant in particular was generated, managed, and mishandled. The nuclear arms race with Russia was still ongoing at the time of the Chernobyl plant's construction, as was the height of the cold war, and Russia was interested in building as many nuclear power plants with as little effort and as little budget as feasibly possible.

Chernobyl's reactor design was already considered to be outdated at the time it was constructed in 1972, and the plant that was built around it was equally outdated and made as cheaply as possible. The design for the plant was so flawed that the emergency stop button you're supposed to hit in the event of a meltdown basically turned the reactor into a giant bomb. NO ONE but the Russians would have or could have built nuclear power plants this way, and even at the time of the plant's construction there were far safer and far better designs for power plants that were more openly utilized in other places of the world.

Since then, safety measures and reactor design has only gotten more advanced over time, including more and much more effective redundancies and precautions. A nuclear power plant built today with modern materials, modern building techniques, and modern reactor designs and framework have next to zero chances of a meltdown of any kind, and every precaution under the sun to hinder, contain, or outright stop a catastrophic reaction should it occur.

I've been saying for a long time that Nuclear energy is not clean, but it is much much cleaner than fossil fuels- yes, the waste is more hazardous, but there is much less of it and it is actually easier to contain.

It's not ideal, but it's the best option we have right now. I am sure that in he future there will be better options, but we don't have time to wait for them.

Also, as for making things electric... IF we were producing more of our electricity by low emissions means, it would definitely be beneficial, but when it comes to heating in particular, it is less efficient to use electrical heating than natural gas.

Electrical heating is almost 100% efficient, because heat is basically the waste product of just about all electrical processes, so all you need to do is make a deliberately inefficient circuit and you get heating. However, burning fossil fuels for electricity is only about 30% efficient, while burning fossil fuels for heat is closer to 70% efficient.

So while having an electric water heater or space heater in your home /seems/ like it should be more efficient, since the device has close to 100% rather than 70% efficiency, it's misleading since 80% of the energy used to power it is produced at 30% efficiency, meaning it ends up closer to ~37% vs 70% Only slightly more than half as efficient as piping gas to your home and using that to produce heat.

And since natural gas is so good at producing heat efficiently, I think there should be more efforts to produce natural gas alternatives in an ecologically friendly way- such as by growing trees, cooking off and capturing the wood gasses, sequestering (landfilling) the Carbon (Charcoal) and burning the wood gas for municipal and residential heating. One major issue that I see in the process of transitioning into electrically powered devices that are traditionally ran off of fossil fuel is the cost efficiency of using electric alternatives;
I work in the field of HVAC, and have done many installations of new equipment, and am now in the area of the field where I do maintenances and repairs of existing equipment,
over 90% of all people in my area get gas furnaces to heat their homes, as well as gas water heaters, the reason isn't cost in the equipment in itself (as the price isn't too significant) it's the cost in running electric furnaces (air handlers with electric strips)/ electric water heaters; over gas powered appliances that are the same size. It's MUCH more costly to use electric appliances than it is gas, and the electric stuff takes longer to heat as well; the only real appliances that have any publicity are the heat pump split systems/mini split systems.
Those are basically air conditioners, that also (in the winter) can be used to create heat instead of cooling, by simply reversing the refrigeration cycle with a reversing valve. The issue, is that when the temperatures outside drop significantly lower, the heat pump loses efficiency, and eventually can't even create heat below a certain outside temperature, which is ironically the time in which you would need it most.

The only people that use electric heating appliances, are ones that live in more remote locations, in which they don't have the option for gas, but most of them would rather opt in for LP, or Oil powered furnaces/appliances as it is cheaper for that fuel over using electricity. If an electric furnace, and water heater were simply cheaper to run than their fossil fuel counterparts, nobody would even use the gas powered appliances, it's an easy sell. When you factor in reprocessing spent fuel, given that 95% some percent of fissile uranium goes unspent in a fuel cell, those uranium and thorium reserves could last far, far longer. It still wouldn't be entirely renewable, but it's enough to last us for the foreseeable future, giving time to develop true renewable tech further.

Secondly, while nuclear plants are very expensive to construct, their operating costs are a fair bit lower than fossil fuel plants, so I'm the long run it's absolutely cheaper. The main issue is getting investors to go in on the huge initial cost, because it does end up taking longer for a nuclear plant to pay itself off compared to a fossil fuel plant, despite the lower operating cost.

Third, nuclear power is safer than fossil fuels by a wide margin. Even accounting for those big disasters, nuclear energy has caused fewer deaths and injuries per watt-hour than any fossil fuel. Once you account for injuries, illness, and deaths resulting from pollution, it becomes even more clear that nuclear is way safer.

Fourth, one of the main obstacles to expanding nuclear power generation is the building waste problem. Even with reprocessing, we're still going to need a long term method of waste disposal. Suffice it to say that while methods for this have been proposed and studied, absolutely nobody is willing to allow the construction of a waste disposal site "in my backyard", i.e. anywhere near them at all. Nobody is willing to let the science people solve the really big problem. For more detailed example, look up the Yucca Mountain Project, and prepare to be profoundly disappointed in humanity.

Finally, as far as I can tell, one of the biggest reasons why fuel reprocessing isn't done right now is because governments are absolutely terrified of anyone getting access to nuclear refining methods because nukes. Nuclear proliferation is a big issue, and it's something I wasn't able to get around to talking about in my essay. To make a long story short, the most compelling solution to this issue is to enforce stricter nuclear disarmament and hopefully remove nukes and mutually assured destruction from the diplomatic equation. To be perfectly honest, I have NO expertise on this particular subject, and the details are beyond me, so take everything I'm saying about the nuke issue with a hefty grain of salt.

Anyway, if anyone wants to see sources, I can provide, but bear in mind that most of what I read were academic journal articles that I accessed through my university (specifically through JSTOR), and might be hard to get to otherwise.

As an engineer in the energy sector, here are the challenges with with nuclear and most renewables:

Renewables:
1) Defining them. A significant portion of "renewables" is "biomass". Much of "biomass" is simply burning trees, bushes and other plant material. This is actually far worse that fossil fuels because

a) it produces more green house gasses and solid particulate pollution that fossil fuels do.
b) it is significantly less efficient (and therefore far more costly) than fossil fuels.
c) it often receives government subsidies and is lauded as a "green" and "renewable" source when it is in fact worse .

2) Consistency. This is a huge issue for solar and wind.

a) Peak electricity usage happens after the sun goes down. Like the video mentioned, storage facilities could help this problem, but facilities large enough to allow solar to power a significant portion of a power grid would be far to expensive to be practicable at this time (not to mention being hard on the environment).

b) Weather. Solar and wind experience frequent and often unpredictable spikes and lulls in production. Unless you want random frequent blackouts you need other predictable and controllable power sources for most the power grid. Because of these variations, no more than 15% of any power grid can consist of solar and wind.

Another big issue that most don't realize is that the other electricity sources have to ramp up or down based on the production based on how much power solar and wind are adding. This adds difficulty and increases costs.

3) Availability. Tidal, geothermal, hydroelectric power do not all of the consistency issues that solar and wind do, but they have a different issue. They are only available in specific and limited areas. As a result, we can not expect any significant increase in power from these sources in the future.

While solar and wind are not bound like those mentioned above, they do have their own location restrictions.

4) Environmental impacts. Renewable energy is not some magical energy source that is perfectly clean and does no harm to the environment, though most of them (biomass being the glaring exception) do produce fewer green house gasses than fossil fuels.

Solar energy plants emit more radiation than nuclear powerplants. They require large amounts of rare earth metals requiring heavy strip mining operations. Their shorter lifespans mean they will have to be replaced about twice as frequently as traditional powerplants.

Wind is far cleaner than solar. While it does kill its share of birds and bats, it does not require the large quantities of rare earth metals that the solar plants require and their production only costs a fraction of the energy (and therefore green house gas emitions) that solar energy plant construction requires.

5) Quantity. Hydro power is the #1 source of renewable power. This along with geothermal and tidal are essentially already producing at their max level most 1st world countries. They will not be able to take over any of the fossil fuel's share of the load.

Wind and solar comprise around 5% - 6% of the US' energy production. Fossil fuels account for 80%. Is it possible for wind and solar to increase production by 1600%?

Nuclear.

1) Long term storage. While nuclear powerplants produce comparatively little waste, part of what it does produce can be dangerously radioactive for many decades. If nuclear energy production is ramped up, we will need long term answers to this problem.

2) Government Regulations. A medium sized powerplant can run for a year on a piece of uranium the size of a car. About 96% of that car sized piece of fuel ran be reprocessed and recycled to be used again in a powerplant. However, such reprocessing is currently illeagal within the US. Back in 1977, President Jimmy Carter banned reprocessing claiming that it was not cost effective and that it could lead to nuclear weapon proliferation. Both claims have since proven false and several other countries currently recycle their spent nuclear fuel for use in their own power plants.



Summary: The cleanest and most consistent renewable energy sources are already largely maxed out. Wind and solar have the potential to expand, but have their variability and inconsistency currently prevents them from providing more that a small percentage of any power grid. That percentage could grow with better energy storage technology, but it is unlikely to ever be the main power source in any decent sized electrical grid. Renewables could shoulder a bigger load, but will never be able to shoulder all or even most our energy needs.

Nuclear power faces popularity issues and in some places regulatory challenges. However, if we want to minimize fossil fuel usage, nuclear power is the one best equipped to carry the load.

the first part of the video, while being a popular view, for many reasons including vested interests, is not proven and current scientific study shows that as CO2 increases in concentration in the atmoshere it's effect diminishes logarimically and is practically nil at the levels we now have.

That said there are so many videos discussing various ways of generating electricity, as this one which puts pros and cons of the various sources.

I have yet to see any videos that discuss the technical aspects of generation and grid stability.

Simply put renewables all are asynchronous sources of power and cannot, by themselves, power a grid. (I.e. they cannot support grid frequency, the most important factor of a grid system. Imagine driving a car whose throttle control was random and the driver has no control over.)

Large nuclear plants run pretty much at a constant maximum power output at all times except for refuelling. (Incidentally the fuel fifty years ago was reprocessed and reused in U.K. Magnox reactors).
This too is less than ideal as the grid load varies; France exports a lot of it's electricty to neighpouring countries to suit their running, if you look at France's demand it is very flat compared to the U.K. for instance.
Small modular recators may be a solution to this negative but there seems little happening in that field?

Where fossil fuel and hydro power plants excel is that they are synchronous and can modulate output as demand (load) fluctuates. Also they have a very high inertia in their generators which smooth out fluctuations on the grid, especially when faults occur. The grid runs to a very tight frquency control and if this variation exceeds 0.5 Hz in the U.K. partial grid trips occur. The reason that there are very few is due to the characteristics of fossil fuel and hydro plants. They're not. They're a small part of the equation and work well in specific environments that uniquely suit them.

The future is nuclear power. It's been the solution since the '60's. It's just that nobody cared to actually implement it to scale and in ways where economies of scale could drive the price down and speed up production to match France and China's timetables.

The real issue is creating more heavy forges needed to produce the reactor pressure vessels. Most everything else is steel for piping and concrete for creating the containment buildings. Those two are not hard to acquire in large quantities such as the millions of tons needed. The heavy forges could pose a challenge because you're essentially creating whole factories for the purpose of building one complex structure.

We're talking about creating an additional 1,500 nuclear plants at 1000 MwE each reactor to power current power needs worldwide. This is easily possible within a generation if people seriously want to solve this issue. Crossing our fingers for some miracle battery tech that doesn't require heavy mining for massive amounts of rare earths, and photovoltaics and wind turbines that don't cause massive carbon footprints to produce is a stupid way to fight climate change. Nuclear power is the most energy-dense power source on the planet, it produces the most low-carbon power per unit of fuel, it can run indefinitely all year, is impervious to weather effects and disasters like hurricanes, works anywhere on the planet, and is a baseload power that can give consistent prices per peak watt unlike intermittent sources. The downsides of nuclear power are virtually nonexistent. one key innovation I rarely see discussed is modulized reactors, it's tech that's already out there, very simple.

The idea is you take those high output reactors that we're used to imagining when we discuss nuclear reactors, and scale the reactor cores themselves down.
The output is definitely going to go down, but if you shrink it down to the 50-250kw output range, you DRAMATICALLY improve the outcomes of any possible accidents.

You can take that small reactor, With as few moving parts inside the reactor as possible.
Build the whole thing in your factory, and ship it to the site, instead of building it onsite, this improves your quality control, and reduces costs.
The reactor cores are designed to be non-human serviceable outside of refueling, reducing human exposure.


You take that reactor, place it inside of your emergency cooling pool of light water, and connect it up to the larger plant cooling and electrical systems, connect up your primary loop to your standard steam turbines... along with a few other identical reactors. By moving your primary systems away from the reactors, you can more safely perform maintenance, and in the event of one cooling or electrical system failure, they can automatically swap to a backup within seconds, no humans needed, and no loss of output.

And in the event of a nuclear excursion, when a full SCRAM is called for, the reactor has it's standard control rods suspended by a powered on electromagnet.
The power to the electromagnet gets cut, and the magnets will reverse polarity, and rods will be forced back down both by gravity and magnetism.

That also means it automatically SCRAMS itself in the event of a facility power failure, like the Fukashima incident.

In the worst case event, the entire reactor module can just be jettisoned into the emergency cooling pool, with the reactor itself doubling as containment as long as needed.

Hydroelectric power, primarily in the form of massive river-wide blockades, is renewable, but *NOT sustainable*.

If we want to continue with Hydro, it needs to take the form of pumped-storage, run-of-the-river, or microhydro. Hydroelectric dams embody a lot of emissions due to CO2 in the concrete, and the water storage upstream often submerges flora, leading to anerobic decomposition and methane release. Methane is x30-90 more potent as a GHG than CO2 depending on the decay time scale observed.

This is also not to mention how river-wide hydroelectric blockades interrupt the natural flow of nutrients and biodiversity, meaning poor ecological performance both upstream and downstream. Standard solid fuel nuclear reactors don't play very well with intermittent renewables when the renewables are given priority in the grid, because when the nuclear plants shut down to let intermittent renewables take over, the nuclear plants have to wait ~3 days before they can start back up again. This is due to poisoning by a very neutron-hungry isotope of Xenon gas that gets created inside the fuel during operation which prevents the reaction from restarting until it decays away (its half life is ~18 hours).

In the mean time the electricity the nukes would be making has to be covered by fossil fuels. It's why adding renewables to Ontario's nuclear-heavy grid was actually causing the CO2 emissions to rise, until they switched the priority from renewables to nuclear.

HOWEVER, molten salt liquid fuel reactors do not have this problem, as the Xenon gas bubbles out of the fuel before it can cause problems, which means these types of reactors can ramp up and down as quick as you like, making them pair very well with intermittent renewables. Their high-temperature operation also allows them to directly replace industrial heating needs, which are currently provided almost completely by fossil fuels.

There's no such thing as renewable energy. The energy being converted into electricity is not returned to the source it was taken from causing that source to operate at a net loss.

For example, the energy converted by solar panels is energy that would otherwise have been returned to the atmosphere via reflection or by being absorbed and later radiated back as heat. The consistent supply of energy from the sun will not replace that lost radiated heat to the atmosphere. The panels will simply continue converting that amount into electricity. Wind turbines have the same basic problem. The energy they convert from the wind is not returned. Thus the wind becomes less energetic on average in areas downwind from turbines. Were we to convert enough energy to meet the majority of the world's needs with such methods, the energy lost from the atmosphere would definitely have an effect on the climate and not likely a beneficial one.

Hydroelectric and possibly geothermal plants would probably be useful secondary sources. However, there's a limit to the amount of feasible sources and damns come with their own negative environmental effects.

Technically, nuclear plants also take without returning. Unlike "renewable" sources however, the energy lost from the decay of the natural nuclear fuels we mine would make up a tiny amount of the overall energy in the atmosphere. When compared to the amount of electricity we can get from those mined fuels, nuclear power becomes the most efficient, least environment altering source available and should be our primary source.

Solar panels are only capable of converting sunlight to electricity at an efficiency rate of roughly 20%, that rate drops slightly over time as solar cells decay. Solar is only effective at capturing energy 12 hours of the day (varying on the latitude and season), the atmosphere also reflects a significant portion of solar rays back into space, the most efficient way to use solar would be to develop solar arrays in orbit and beam energy back to the surface, but that is currently infeasible. Windpower is hugely oversold as a potential renewable energy source as it costs far more land area to develop an array of wind turbines that produce significantly less energy than a nuclear power plant that uses a fraction of the same amount of land but produces exceedingly more energy than can ever be attained by current or future windpower technology. There are also other forms of nuclear reactors that are significantly less risk-averse than current nuclear reactors using different substances as coolant or reinvented as new reactor designs, I am an avid believer in Liquid Floride Thorium Reactors as one alternative to many renewable sources of energy.

A huge reason that safe nuclear power has such a problem gaining a foothold is because it gets such bad press. Basically only academics are actually familiar with them, and only a small handful of science communicators actually push hard to get people to understand that 'modern' reactors are much safer. Quotations around 'modern' because these designs have been around for decades, but never got off the ground because the big nuclear countries wanted to focus more on Uranium because the enrichment process is necessary to weaponise uranium.

Even then, as bad as uranium is, it's still way safer than people think. Chernobyl and Fukushima both had serious problems; Chernobyl was an outdated design that wasn't properly maintained, and being run by people that weren't properly trained and Fukushima was built in a tsunami prone area with many analysts telling the owners that an accident like what happened was inevitable years before it actually took place. Also, meltdowns aren't explosive. I see so many people characterise meltdowns like they're nukes, when all it is is the nuclear material inside the reactor melting through its containment (which, by the way, a solution has been found for this problem that makes meltdowns entirely safe; now it just shuts down the plant by dumping the material into a reservoir deep underground where it can cool down).

If the average person understood this, nuclear would be widely considered a highly viable energy source, and would likely be used in every developed nation. It frustrates me so much that the main argument against modern nuclear energy basically boils down to 'people don't want it', which is such a horseshit answer. It's like getting rid of vaccines because an uneducated group of people think they're dangerous.

One concern with Nuclear is that here in Australia, mines are run by private entities, which would be fine if they followed the given safety procedures, but they rarely do, so now a uranium mine has made an adjacent national park a health risk due to radiation exposure, and they own the government so they're not punished for their mistakes. I know the materials for renewable energy mechanisms also need to be mined, but at least we can evolve it to the point of recycling through innovation and investment, whereas nuclear materials requires constant mining. In a country like ours with a whole lot of boiling hot desert and not much else. Renewables such as wind and solar are just safer and less open to corporate greed and complacency. There's a lot more nuance here that needs to be addressed, and I think Kurzgesagt has a duty to do so as it is easily one of the most popular and influential outlets of science communication and education.

First off, part of the problem is that anti-renewable politics are far more politically powerful than anti-nuclear politics, and the former has often cynically latched onto nuclear energy to divert efforts away from true renewables. This can be seen in the lobbying and public influence work done by orgs such as the Heartland Institute and AEI. These groups are funded by the oil industry and only seem to believe climate change exists when it's time to virtue signal about nuclear. Furthermore, there's a perception that this diversion is exactly what fossil fuel and extractive industries want. Nuclear also just requires way more work to make politically palatable in general, due to public fears, unfounded or otherwise. It elicits such emotions that some people will NEVER be convinced. There's an additional concern, one that I'm not convinced of, that nuclear could become an entrenched interest, a new Big Oil that becomes difficult to phase out in spite of any negative externalities.

Thus, the worry among even environmentalists open to nuclear like myself is that giving any political oxygen to nuclear will exhaust political will, activist energy, and economic capital and slow the transition. You said it best Kurzgesagt: "why make it harder on ourselves?" It's already hard politically to transition from fossil fuels. Scientists, techies, and engineers tend to trivialize the work that goes into changing hearts and minds, but as someone whose been trying for over a decade, unpacking the baggage of nuclear, enough to make it viable, is a practically Herculean task in its own right. I gave up in 2018 when became clear that we can no longer wait for the ideal politics to materialize, and we have to pivot.

I'm also pretty disappointed that Kurzgesagt failed to address by far the most promising source of renewable baseload power in the near term: geothermal power. Thanks to fracking tech, called EGS when used for geothermal, it's now possible to create artificial hot springs anywhere in the world using only water as a transfer medium. It requires less effort and funding to make politically feasible and increase efficiency, and it's already more cost-effective than nuclear in most of the world. And regarding induced seismicity, despite early hiccups, it's actually safer than fracking as the pressure in the wells is lower and applied evenly. Conveniently, it also makes use of tech, equipment, and skills that were pioneered by oil and gas as well as the latest geological exploration tools developed by Big Tech. Thus it represents the perfect political compromise: totally clean, relatively safe power with minimal effect on the environment, no need for re-skilling oil & gas employees, and it gives FF companies a stake in real decarbonization, not some carbon capture synfuel fantasy land.

Lastly, these solutions are still, despite the hurdles, not all-or-nothing. Where there are political roadblocks to nuclear, i.e. The Americas, Western Europe, Japan, attention could be focused on EGS and it's shallower and simpler cousin AGS. In fact, that's already started to happen. In quake-prone Japan, buildings, infrastructure, and most importantly people are more tolerant of earthquakes than they are of nuclear energy. Thus, the Japanese gov't, while ice-cold to nuclear, has broken down regulatory hurdles for EGS and is investing directly into its development.

It would be a hard sell on many fronts, so it probably won't happen, but it is technologically possible right now to build a nearly carbon neutral coal-fired power plant. This does NOT mean it is possible to retrofit existing, inefficient coal-fired power plants to this level of emissions, but some carbon reduction tech has and should continue to be deployed on these. A newly constructed plant however could incorporate all the proven carbon reduction technologies, plus newer sequestration methods, not to mention be nearly 100 percent efficient. Two big reasons among many that make such facilities unlikely to be constructed is a lack of political will and the lack of an economic imperative. In the US, coal power plants of any type are a political non-starter in some areas, as equally in other areas are regulations making next-gen pollution controls such as these mandatory. Power companies cannot build where they are not allowed to, and will do so in the least expensive way, incorporating cost adding pollution controls, despite improved efficiency, only as the law requires, and carbon emissions still do not have any associated costs either. It is a real shame that even a few of these facilities will probably never be built, because of the over 300 years of coal reserves in the US alone, a many-decades-worth portion of these are already mined, sitting outside of old existing power plants. If we took that existing mined coal, and used it to fuel new plants like this, it would at least buy us some much needed time to electrify everything and give installation of renewables and energy storage technology and infrastructure a better chance to catch up and take the lead. It is paradoxical to think about, but most of the people on earth would not be alive in the first place if not for fossil fuels.  Throughout human history, the population of the planet grew slowly and the quality and length of life was poor and short.  Consider the world population around the year 1000 C.E. was about 400 million people.  By the time just before the  industrial revolution the population had grown to around 790 million people.  In 750 years the population grew by about 390 million people.  If we did not have the industrial revolution and continued on that trajectory, we would be at around 930 million people by 2020.  Instead, our population has grown almost exponentially to around 7,350 million people.  Those 6,420 million people would not be alive if not for the industrial revolution and the abundance of inexpensive energy it provided.  Now consider life expectancy.  In 1750 life expectancy was around 35 years; today it is about 78 years.  This increase is directly attributable to the advancements in technology that would not have been possible without the energy derived from burning fossil fuels.  Lastly, consider economic growth.  The world economy was pretty consistent for most of human history.  One measure of that is GDP per capita (not an ideal analogue but one that is easily researched).  According to a study done by British economist Angus Maddison, the world GDP per capita in 1700 was around $616 (measured in 1990 international dollars).  By the year 2008 that had risen to $7,614, a more than 12 fold increase.  It is easy to "blame" fossil fuels for the harm that they cause, I am not saying that they do not have negative effects. The problem with "Why won't we try all the ways" argument is that renewable generation is already MUCH cheaper than nuclear.
Easiest comparison - CFD contracts in the UK for offshore wind are being sold for less than 40 GBP/MWh (and they are actually making money and don't get any other direct subsidy, even financing comes from private banks), while the same CFD for nuclear is above 100 GBP/MWh (and they are losing money and require a lot of extra government support, including insurance and financing). So, the straightforward argument here is that for the time and money to build a single nuclear plant, we can build 4 times capacity of renewable.

And, it takes 2-3 yrs including FEED phase to add 1 GW capacity in wind offshore and more than 10 yrs (easily more than 15 yrs with FEED and permitting) to build similar capacity in nuclear, which adds to risks. And the offshore wind is getting cheaper, while traditional nuclear is getting more expensive. And safety and insurance issue. And special requirements to security. And non-prolifiteration issues. And the operator will be firmly attached to a single fuel producer (which can be a huge political issue). Note, I didn't even talk about waste yet...

Of course, system cost is not only generation cost, we need to manage swings in power supply from renewables. But, conceptually, it is not that different for nuclear - nuclear power cannot be (cheaply) adjusted up and down to meet the demand requirements. Flex power nuclears have huge cost per MWh, and normal solution is to export excess power to neighboring countries, which has similar destructive effect on the grid as renewables do. And since nuclear needs scale, the grids have to be rebuilt about multi-GW monsters, which is a lot of extra cost and time.

Also, we can't really quickly ramp up nuclear construction - building and operating the plants requires very specialized skills from the developer, operator and regulators. It also requires creation of very specialize infrastructure. You can't just bring and drop such technology to a new country, it takes decades and billions of $$ just to build the framework of operation and regulations and etc.. This is not a process that anybody is willing to accelerate, and it is understandable. Everywhere where the nuclear energy is successful, it is feeding from synergy with an active nuclear weapon program (and transfers some hidden costs there).

Indeed, we need to keep investing into nuclear, but the traditional nuclear business models do not work for a long time already. The nuclear generation will remain a niche solution for decades to come. Modular nuclear plants sound promising, but we nothing yet about their cost and reliability. Maybe they will find a nice niche in the new markets - e.g., green H2 production.

This vid repeats a lot of the nonsense arguments put forward by the nuclear lobby. My response:

1. Nuclear is a non-renewable resource and the industry is already dealing with shortages of Uranium. The National Nuclear Regulatory Commission has stated that approving plans for different types of plants could take 25+ years.

2. The nuclear industry has been lobbying heavily for years for funds to extend the lifetime of their business. In doing so, they seek to redirect funds that could otherwise be used to improve renewable energy production technology. Since nuclear isn't viable in the longterm (and many of the new designs have notable flaws) this lobbying effort is motivated more by a desire for job security than altruism.

3. The IPCC has stated in their report that it was likely possible to meet the 2050 zero emmisions goal with only renewables, but that they didn't explore that option because they wanted to reflect what countries were already doing (using nuclear.) Basically, the argument that renewables can't meet our needs is still unproven.

4. The true cost of nuclear lies not only in the prohibitive costs of designing, approving and commissioning plants, but in the disposal, which has mostly been borne by taxpayers. The safety issues involved are another significant problem that needs to be addressed before further investment in nuclear should even be considered.

Basically, it boils down to what we want to spend our money on. Clean renewable technology that can likely meet our needs if we commit to it, or dirty tech that is astronomically expensive and will fail us in 50 or so years while leaving a huge radioactive mess to clean up? 🤷‍♀️

i am a proponent of new age nuclear, and there is sense of urgency amongst the nuclear community since the development of these new reactor designs take time, something we have to take well into account. We cannot keep dragging our feet on this. But one undeniable fact is that when we engage mass production of one particular new age reactor design, the price, duration of construction drops drastically, France had it and did it cheaply when their nuclear reactor golden age in the 1975 to 1985. Furthermore, the new age reactor designs (large designs) are smaller even still due to their new attributes and innate passive safety that does not require a massive pressure containment structure.

If each new reactor core, be it from the European SAMOFAR project or LFTR projects, generates in excess 1.6 GWe, each reactor replaces 800 onshore windmills (with an average capacity of 2MW), however without taking capacity factor in mind which averages in the US at about 35%, which sees the number of wind turbines it replaces becoming 2285 units. And with a life span of 20 years, you would have to construct the same fleet of wind turbines a total of 3 times to achieve the same life span coverage of a nuclear reactor of 60 years, which can even increase if the maintenance was provided. This sees the number of windmills 1 nuclear reactor replaces multiplied 3 times over, making the realistic number of windmills "6850". Offshore windmills fare a little better with an average capacity of 3.4MW and a higher Capacity factor seeing an average of 50%, giving the following numbers, 440 replaced by the nuclear reactor, and 880 replaced after the capacity factor is calculated into it. And to achieve the same lifespan of 60 years, we are still looking at a grand total of 2640 offshore windmills.

We are at a tipping point, Nuclear reactor designing has been stagnant and stale due to lack of support and funding since the late 1980s, however nuclear reactor energy can be the most effective and quickest to roll out and combat climate change than any other option. However, we have waited too long, it takes serious spending in R&D today, now, to ensure we have a commercially viable design in time (hopefully by 2030), so that the industry can shoulder the transition and bring out a fleet of quick, reliable, safe, cheap, carbon zero, and massive amounts of electricity. If we wait too long the new age reactors won't come in time to combat rapid and self-sustaining climate change.

By the year 2035 or 2040 our industries are going to be more occupied replacing current fleets of windmills and solar panels rather than expanding it, besides all the low-hanging fruit and easy locations where we can fit windmills will be occupied soon and getting the same capacity factor is going to become harder and harder. It stands to reason that the "Not in my backyard" mentality will show up hard considering the number of windmills and solar panel needed to be placed.

This isn't to say we should stop Wind and Solar Technology from being happening, quite the contrary, but as it has been shown, the expansion of renewables is too slow to keep up with current expansion. We strongly believe nuclear energy if properly funded and developed and commercialized can be rolled out much faster and cheaper than renewables once it reaches economical maturity. We need to increase capacity factors, we need to increase lifespans, and we need to increase the recycleability of the windmills and solar panels before we can rely on this technology, and i don't see this happening in time.

I would strongly recommend that you treat nuclear energy in this light, New Age Nuclear is so much more potent, than the already existing Nuclear technology which is from the 1960s and 1970s and still manages to compete with current energy sources. But the transition, the funding, the will needs to happen now... if it is to be available before it is too late.

The biggest problem is the human problem.

Humanity has the proven historical problem of 'patch and pray.' We fix something just enough to call something 'mission complete' and then quickly move onto whatever we perceive as our next challenge without actually addressing everything. It is how we got here today.

Renewable energy is not a new technology. For example, we've had the first solar cell since 1880 (you can fact check that). The problem was that we needed energy quickly and cheaply, so solar development took a long waited back seat (141 years). Things like coal were abundant and easy to burn. Our energy needs were labeled 'mission complete.' Whatever problems we perceived by burning were not addressed, leaving it to generations later to figure out (which we are doing, now).

Nuclear is another coal in that sense. It is quick and easy, but we know it causes harmful waste. Yet, we are eager to label this as the solution to achieve our 'mission complete' status once more. And just like coal, once in place, we risk repeating history, not being so eager to address those problems until they become critical, just like we did coal.

The goal is to save the planet while also not repeating history, replacing one harmful waste with another. This is why nuclear is often looked down upon. I'm just as confident the people who once said they could make coal "clean" (that never happen, now did it) are the same type of people who today say, someday we can make nuclear 'clean' too. Until you can actually do it, we shouldn't be in a hurry to be building out nuclear (let's not be conned again or make similar past mistakes).

"In a world that's already having a really hard time quitting fossil fuels, why should we make things harder than necessary?"

Because everything is in equation of short term AND long term profit for anyone in a position of power and responsibility for these sorts of decisions. Nuclear power IS a good investment for the future, but setting a plant up can take a very long time, and is a very expensive process that will take decades to pay off on its own.

Leaving the cost aside, you also have to consider that in a politically unstable world, war and/or terrorism is not out of the question. The damage one could cause by attacking a country's power infrastructure is far more limited if it's composed of many fossil fuel power plants, compared to the fallout and environmental destruction that could follow a catastrophic failure of a nuclear plant instead.

At least with the risk factor in mind, dealing with the aftermath of a huge fire is preferable to potential radiation fallout, and that might well be why some countries are shutting down their nuclear power plants, especially if they're of considerable age with insufficient security in place, as remodeling them to modern standards may well be more expensive than building a new one, similar to when you need an old device repaired but the cost of the materials and job involved cost more than a new one. Decommissioning the old, and (potentially) building a new one later might just incur the least loss.

There are some major issue with nuclear energy. It's not just the storage of the waste that would still be produced even with newer generations of nuclear power plants. We simply don't have have enough ressources to completely switch to nuclear energy. The worlds energy demand increases drastically, but much like oil, coal or gas, Uranium, which is the base material for every nuclear fossil, is limited. And not only that, we cannot even use all of it.

Most Uranium available is the stable isotope Uranium 238 (99.28 %), which is basically useless for energy production. In order to get nuclear fuels, we have to get it from the natural Uranium, by enrichment or by making Uranium decay into Plutonium. These are processes we can handle, but are extremely costly and the know ho is not available to everyone. Not to mention that not every country in the world has access to Uranium deposits.

Also there is a geopolitical component. Several treaties forbid sharing the know-how to enrich Uranium, because of the fear it could be used for weapons. And to be fair, it could. That's why the knowledge is strictly limited and every attempt to gain that knowledge, is strictly monitored by every global power. This situation would also place countries possessing Uranium deposits in a very strong position, forming a global cartell, regulating the flow of fuel to their own liking. Much like the OPEC does with oil. And that could lead to similiar crisis like the 1973 oil crisis.


So what's the alternative? Well, while we could increase the share of nuclear energy on the global market, we won't be able to cover our energy demand with it. Especially since the reduction of carbondioxide means, we need to electrify every aspect of our lives. Traffic, industry, private homes, everything. Good estimates tell us, that we would at least increase our demand for eletrical energy by a factor of 2.5 to 3. That's impossible to achieve only with nuclear energy. Except we manage to get nuclear fusion running anytime soon. But let's be honest, even if ITER and other projects are succesful, the first commercially usable power plants won't be available until the late 2050s or even later. Too late.

Instead we should focus on a better mixture, including not only modernized nuclear energy, but also renewable energies, water and energy storage technologies. That doesn't even exclude the usage of renewable fossils, like gas from plants and fecals.

Some thoughts about nuclear power:

Kurzgesagt is talking about doing something against global warming with nuclear plants!

Every year there are more days in the summer when you can't cool down nuclear power plants because the temperature of the rivers is already too high. So they have to be shut down completely.

Many nuclear power plants are located in coastal areas. With rising sea levels, many sites may have to be abandoned!

We cannot use most of the existing power plants much longer for safety reasons. Most of them are already dangerously old and have reached the end of their service life! Extending these lifetimes would be very risky because most of the material of the reactors and the cooling circuits is already fatigued.

New plants would be finished in 5 years at the earliest, if the construction would start TODAY! That is MUCH too late for avoiding the climate change!

But those "modern reactors" do not even exist in reality yet, there are no prototypes! Research and development of those devices would take decades and consume billions of money. Time we don't have for fighting climate change and money that could be put to a better use a lot quicker.

It's not like we could just "dump" all the existing nuclear waste into a "new kind of reactor" and then "burn" it or "melt" it until most of it is gone. Only a small percentage of all existing nuclear material could be used. But there are no known technical processes yet that could manage to separate the waste. Again, many years of development and billions of dollars needed.

EVEN IF it were possible RIGHT NOW, those processing facilities would still have to be invented, planned and built. Again: time we don't have and lots of money!

The existing nuclear waste, which supposedly "could be processed so well," is now at many different sites. Many transports would be necessary, each one posing a danger to anyone involved or living along the transport route.

According to best guesses and the most favorable estimates, a maximum of 5% of the current waste could be used for "transmutation". So we still need repositories for at least 95% of the existing atomic waste!

All the money that would have to be pumped into building new nuclear reactors would be better invested in solar and wind energy and storage technology.

Ask yourselves why NO investors are willing to give money for such projects. You cannot buy shares for nuclear power world wide. Even in the past, companies and investors have invested only if states have given several guarantees. In most cases, it was the states themselves that financed nuclear power plants because they have an interest in weapons-grade material. France's nuclear company is effectively bankrupt, and the construction of their latest nuclear power plant is taking almost twice as long as planned already. And it got more and more expensive over time.

Once it becomes unburied, we either burn it immediately, or it eventually becomes a gas through some other process. Let me be nit-picky about one small detail: the blast furnace is used for reduction of the iron ore (iron oxides), i.e., for separating the iron from the oxygen. Electric arc furnaces are not capable of doing that. They are used for processing iron in its reduced form (steel scrap), essentially a form of recycling. Iron/steel recycling is already quite high (over 70%) and yet is not enough to supply the current demand, so the need for iron produced from ore.

Coal is used in the reduction iron ore because at high temperatures carbon bonds more strongly with oxygen than iron. This is basic principle of the reduction of any metal ore. Coal also has the right strength to support the weight of the ore in the blast furnace and, of course, is the cheapest option. In some places (e.g., Brazil), for some specific applications and limited production volumes, charcoal (renewable source) is used as an alternative to coal, but other issues arise, remarkably the use of slave labour for its production.

Electrolysis of liquid iron ore is currently not viable. The seemingly most prominent solution nowadays is direct reduction of iron ore by direct reduction of iron oxide by hydrogen. But most of the hydrogen produced today comes from methane reforming (releases CO2), as electrolysis of water is very energy intensive, and therefore, expensive (due to the strong covalent bond between oxygen and hydrogen).

It superficially seems cheaper to continue using the coal power plant you already have than to build a new anything. There's also a lot of corrupt and ideological western politicians who obsess over coal (to preempt the whataboutism here, not saying that, say, China is amazing or anything, just that they don't share this specific flaw). The result is that we're bottlenecked by effort, not the capability of renewable power. If we were to "also" invest in nuclear that funding would come out of the "mitigate climate change" funding and just decrease renewable deployment, and since in many areas renewable power is already cheaper to deploy than anything else that would actually worsen emissions.

Having said that continuing to run existing reactors and rolling new ones out where it is efficient to do so does make sense, I just don't see it working in any way that would improve things in western countries. Germany etc should keep their existing reactors running and refurb them but building new ones at this point will just slow down renewables by about the same amount.

It is actually a lot less efficient to use electricity for heating specifically instead of burning the fossil fuels at the point of usage.  When you burn fossil fuels to heat a house 100% of the potential chemical energy gets converted to heat.  Compare that to a fossil fuel power station that only converts between 35% to 45% of the potential energy to electricity (the rest is converted to unwanted heat at the power station).  Add another 6% loss over the electricity grid and only 29% to 39% of potential chemical energy ends up heating the house.  So the power plant needs to burn more than twice the fuel for you to get the same heat out.  This is a serious factual slipup.

Combined-cycle natural gas generators also need to be considered, especially as replacements for coal power plants. Natural gas is relatively cleaner than all other fossil fuels, and next generation combined cycle gas plants are ultra-efficient. The other nice thing about them is they are dispatchable, that is to say you can start one up in minutes if there's more demand on the electricity grid, whereas a nuclear reactor takes days to start up. So if there's an unexpectedly cloudy day, utilities can bring a combined-cycle gas plant online just long enough until the sun comes back out and solar generation picks back up. Many countries currently use coal or even giant diesel generators to provide dispatchable power, so replacing them with gas in the medium term would be a net reduction in emissions. This dispatchable power is different from the baseload power that nuclear can provide, and one day batteries will probably provide most of the dispatchable power and baseload power that's needed, but in the medium term I think we need new natural gas plants just as much as we need nuclear.

I have a few qualms with how solar and wind are presented here. They are simply too energy dilute to be truly viable.

In order to power current world needs (which are growing), we would need to cover the equivalent of the entire country of Spain in solar panels (roughly 200,000sqmi). This produces a number of problems. At that scale we begin to run into manufacturing as a major pollution concern, as large quantities of metal and plastic must be produced for the purpose (including handling, use, and disposal of hazardous materials). Economically, it is incredibly expensive and resource intensive to produce this many panels. Practically, panels must be located in areas which receive enough sun of a proper intensity. Electricity will need to travel from these areas to where it is needed, and this factor is pretty much prohibitive for many countries which are sufficiently far from the equator. Large solar installations also come with some serious environmental concerns like land clearing, displacement of wildlife, disposal of depleted/damaged materials, and harm to birds.

Wind is FAR worse. In order to power the world it would take roughly 2.3 million sqmi of wind farms. It is the most unreliable source of energy in common use (about half as reliable as solar, which is the 3rd least reliable. Hydro is the 2nd least reliable). It requires far more land clearing and has an even worse impact on wildlife, particularly birds. In the production of 1 wind turbine roughly 250 tons of CO2 is released. The use case for wind is so minimal that it is completely laughable to suggest that it could play a major factor in world energy production.

Now a comparison to nuclear. 1000-MW nuclear energy plant can be placed on 1sqmi, vs 50sqmi for solar (in an area of good sun) and 250sqmi for wind (in an area of good wind quality). Nuclear is the most reliable energy source. Nuclear is the safest energy source, with 0.04 deaths per terrawatt hour (0.15 for wind, 0.44 solar, 1.4 hydro, 4 gas, 36 oil, 161 coal. This metric includes deaths from accidents, like Chernobyl, along with construction and operation). The new generation of thorium reactors are projected to produce 1/1000th the amount of waste that current nuclear technologies use. This video acknowledges that waste can be turned into new fuel, and in general there are technologies emerging that capture energy from radioactive waste to be used in the power grid or for other use cases. Nuclear fuel has the potential to be almost completely waste free.

So yes, solar is the future if you are thinking about a dyson array...but while we are bound to earth nuclear is the only viable option. If you don't believe me, try pricing out solar and wind options for your home (exclude subsidies - which is a way of distributing losses across society - for a more honest cost/benefit analysis).

Tiny footnote: You briefly mention breeder reactors. The way these work is that they convert 238U (which is the vast majority of Uranium, around 99.2%, but can't directly be used for nuclear fission) into Plutonium (which can be used for nuclear fission). This means that, for the same amount of mined Uranium, you can get around 100x the nuclear fuel, cutting down on waste by about that same factor, and the waste that you're left with mostly has a shorter lifetime than what you get without breeder reactors. However, there are two challenges. First, you need to engineer your breeder reactor to do the conversion to Plutonium, which means you're optimizing it for something other than simply producing energy as efficiently and effectively as possible, which leads to tradeoffs. But that's fine, that seems worth it, and we can do it, in principle. The second problem is the real killer: it is much, much, much easier to do the sort of refining and enriching necessary to make a nuclear bomb when you're working with Plutonium rather than Uranium, so anti-proliferation treaties tend to discourage or ban producing Plutonium on purpose. And, honestly, as much as I love nuclear energy and the idea of breeder reactors, that kind of makes sense. I think that we should work on it, work toward a world where we can trust each other enough to feel good about producing Plutonium for the sake of even cleaner and more efficient nuclear energy, but we should have a century or two in which to work out the political details necessary for that, so I think it's worth waiting on breeder reactors and work with nuclear energy without breeder reactors while we're figuring that out.

some other points against nuclear energy:

-nuclear energy is NOT renewable. nobody ever talks about the impacts of uranium mining and the fact that it's a limited resource.

-radioactive waste disposal sites are often located in areas populated by vulnerable communities, often bipoc. not to mention said sites are completely inadequate for realistic long-term storage and are grossly mismanaged and often even go unused. (John Oliver did an excellent piece on nuclear waste disposal sites, i'd highly recommended watching it to better understand these issues)

-the accuracy around the statistics of nuclear accidents is questionable at best. we can't truly fathom the long-term consequences or accurately gauge the death toll caused by illness due to long-term radiation exposure (cancers, birth defects, genetic disease, etc) so the numbers may often be biased and negative effects go overlooked.

-people often talk about the low statistical probability of nuclear accidents, which is true, but they fail to acknowledge the sheer devastation and irreversible damage that can come from accidents when they do happen. nuclear accidents are MUCH more severe than other types of accidents.

-nuclear accidents are NOT completely preventable, and the more we use nuclear energy on a widespread scale, the more likely they are to happen. and as stated in Murphy's law, anything that can go wrong will go wrong. when you play with nuclear fire, you're eventually going to get burned.

-energy production costs money, and businesses love to cut corners to maximize profit. if nuclear energy were to be treated as a business and not a service, companies would be completely willing to do the absolute bare-minimum when it comes to safety in order to make as much money as possible. not to mention that laws and regulations have hardly ever stopped companies from questionable practices in the past.

-safety regulations would differ from country to country. look at the countries currently most responsible for pollution and emissions and ask yourself if you would trust them to responsibility and honestly maintain their nuclear facilities.

-lots of people in the comments are talking about how the downsides to nuclear energy can be minimized with funding and research, but the exact same can be said for renewable energy sources. also as i stated before, you can never completely negate the risks.

that being said, i'm not completely against nuclear energy. i just think we should limit the scale on which it is used and focus primarily on renewable energy, with nuclear power being a sort of backup/supplement until we can completely switch to renewable energy only.
