As much as I like your videos, I think you guys gloss over some pretty important practical considerations for nuclear. For one thing, it is a little disingenuous to claim in one video that nuclear is safe, then say in the next video that costs for nuclear energy are only high because of regulation. The regulations are what makes it safe; safety is fundamentally what is incurring the high cost. You also don't mention at all the nuclear weapon proliferation/nuclear terrorism risk that comes with a significant expansion of nuclear power around the world.

Secondly, when addressing climate change, there are pretty important economic factors that likely make renewables + storage a better solution short term. The important thing is that renewables have a lower up front cost and construction time. The lower up front cost makes it easier to attract investors/political capital for renewable projects than it is for nuclear, and makes it faster to pay off the debt to reinvest in new projects. If we are investing in nuclear at the cost of renewables, then there is a huge emissions opportunity cost that comes from the delays in decommissioning fossil fuel power sources while you wait for your nuclear investment to pay off. It just doesn't make sense to have 10-20 years of emissions while a new nuclear plant is constructed, when we could have invested the same amount of money in a larger production capacity in renewables + storage that is ready in 5 years, and nearly paid off before the nuclear plant has produced a single kWh.

Finally, I just want to point out that most of the new energy production capacity over the next century is likely to come from developing countries, where the two points I have mentioned become even more important. These countries unfortunately tend to have poorer regulatory structure, so human factors in safety become a much larger consideration. In addition they are going to be more susceptible to conflict and the effects of climate change, so nuclear plants are more likely to be hit by situations outside of design parameters. Under these conditions, the idea that nuclear is strictly safer than other energy sources becomes a much harder sell. Probably more importantly, these countries tend to have cash flow problems, so the high up-front costs for nuclear are also super problematic.

Overall, while I agree with your thesis that nuclear is an important part of the energy equation, I think you have done yourself a disservice by overselling its effectiveness at fighting climate change. While we shouldn't be rushing to shut down nuclear power plants, and we should be continuing research advanced reactor designs, we also shouldn't be rushing to build nuclear if it comes at the cost of renewables. There are situations where new nuclear reactors will be warranted, but it will likely be much more limited than what you seem to imply in the video. If we were having this discussion 20 years ago, when renewables were significantly more expensive and we had more time to fight climate change, then a large expansion in nuclear would probably have been the way forward (at least in the western world). There may be a time in the future when new designs or changing economic factors means that investment in nuclera makes sense again. As it stands we've run out of time, and "big nuclear" to solve climate change doesn't really make sense anymore.

If I am wrong, I would love to see these points addressed in a future video!

The problem isn't the risk of nuclear energy, but the priorities of people within the energy sector, and industry in general. As long as there are corners to cut, costs to be saved, and profits to be prioritized, Nuclear will never be safe enough to completely replace fossil fuels with.

It's not simply the costs of constructing Nuclear power plants that should be considered, but the costs of disaster prevention, mitigation, and clean up. And it's these costs that have bankrupted countries and governments that have had to handle then. The Soviet Union essentially collapsed dealing with the literal fallout of Chernobyl, and the Fukushima disaster not only muted Japan's economic gains last decade, but it is something that the government will have to keep pouring money into for the rest of it's existence, and will be a permanent strain on the country's future economic development.

And that's not even getting into the human and environmental costs of dealing with these disasters either. Had luck not have been with us in either of these events, Much of Eastern Europe would still be uninhabitable, Sendai would've become the largest abandoned city in the world, and dealing with the effects of the disaster would simply be a fact of life in Tokyo, Minsk, and nearly any major population center close enough to be effected by either of these disasters.

I do think Nuclear energy could be an option in the future, but there has to be a major paradigm shift in humanity first. We simply can't have a safe nuclear energy sector in a profit driven and wealth obsessed society. It's what's preventing these facilities from being developed in the first place, and it will certainly ensure disasters like Fukushima will happen in the future. I mean we must have this paradigm shift to even solve climate change in the first place.

While at university more than a decade ago, I led an undergrad group project looking into the very broad subject of energy and its production for human use. Of the myriad classification criteria we had available - renewable vs. non-renewable, fossil vs. 'green', etc. - we decided to employ centralized vs. distributed as our basic taxonomy. Source availability, infrastructure requirements and scalability are all factors that determine whether a particular type of energy fits best within these two categories.

For example: Nuclear energy, at least with our current models of production, requires fulfilling extensive infrastructure needs - such as fuel sourcing, facility security and waste disposal processes to name a few. Therefore the scale of production must be large enough to outweigh these tradeoffs. Contrast this with wind or solar - which can and are widely deployed at much, much smaller scale; my friends have both solar panels and a wind generator on their sailboat. They are apples to oranges in this sense that they fulfill different energy needs.

The better comparison for Nuclear exists between it and other centralized sources such as legacy fossil fuel. Therefore I argue nuclear to be far superior choice both environmentally and economically in the long run.

Nuclear fission energy should honestly be the energy we focus on using as an alternative to fossil fuels. Not to mention, there’s already talk and development on nuclear fusion energy, which could be very beneficial and is way less risky. What I tend to see as the counterpoints to nuclear (fission) energy relies on the “what ifs.” The three major and notable nuclear disasters that have occurred have been Chernobyl, Fukushima, and Three Mile Island. Chernobyl was due to poor building and management. Fukushima was due to poor timing of events (the tsunami that hit the generators, not allowing the nuclear power plant’s core to cool down). And in Three Mile island, which was what made many people afraid of nuclear energy, the containment building actually did its job and prevented a total meltdown. There are a few others that have happened in history, but those are the most known three. The only problems I see with nuclear energy is the waste it produces and storing it, since the half life of much of the waste is very long and there aren’t many outside places to store it. Also, I remember seeing that nuclear power plants in France use a different type of uranium than we do in the U.S.. The uranium they use is a lot more prevalent in the world compared to the one we use. France also uses a different type of nuclear power plant structure than we do, which I think is related to the type of uranium they use. I honestly wish that nuclear energy was a more popular idea, but many people are scared of the possible outcomes, even though the chances of a meltdown at all are very low. Maybe we’ll have nuclear fusion in the near future, which would be very nice.
